title: Intussusception
setup_script: “A 12-month-old previously healthy boy is brought to the emergency department with a history of episodic inconsolable crying and drawing up of his legs. His mother reports several episodes of vomiting and noticed a dark, jelly-like stool in his diaper earlier today. On arrival, the child appears intermittently lethargic between episodes of distress. How would you proceed in evaluating and managing this patient?”

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 90/50 mmHg, HR 140 bpm, RR 30/min, Temp 37.8 °C.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident observes patient during an episode
dynamic_flow.reply: Child cries inconsolably with knees drawn to chest, then becomes lethargic between episodes.
Sausage-shaped mass palpated in the right upper quadrant; abdomen otherwise soft.
Target and pseudokidney signs consistent with ileocolic intussusception.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays diagnosis or intervention
dynamic_flow.reply: Child becomes more lethargic, tachycardic, and develops abdominal distension; risk of ischemia and perforation increases.
CBC shows mild leukocytosis; type and cross obtained.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident initiates IV access, fluids, and nasogastric decompression
dynamic_flow.reply: Child stabilizes; ongoing episodes persist but perfusion improves.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident proceeds with pneumatic (air) enema reduction under radiologic guidance
dynamic_flow.reply: Successful reduction; passage of air into terminal ileum; child’s symptoms resolve.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If enema fails or signs of perforation occur
dynamic_flow.reply: Exploratory laparotomy performed; reduction achieved, with inspection for lead point such as Meckel’s diverticulum.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident is asked to describe operative steps
dynamic_flow.reply: Examiner requests description of laparotomy, manual reduction techniques, and inspection of bowel for ischemia or lead points.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays reduction despite signs of deterioration
dynamic_flow.reply: Patient progresses to peritonitis and septic shock.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident inquires about recurrence risk
dynamic_flow.reply: Recurrence occurs in ~10%, most within 24 hours; observation overnight warranted.
Provides instructions on signs of recurrence and when to return for medical attention.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident asks about typical lead points
dynamic_flow.reply: Meckel’s diverticulum, polyps, lymphoma, Henoch–Schönlein purpura (more common in older children).
Child remains stable, tolerates feeds, discharged with parental education and follow-up arranged.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of intussusception based on history, exam, and ultrasound
Use of nonoperative enema reduction as first-line therapy
Recognition of failure or perforation requiring surgical intervention
Ability to describe operative reduction and inspection for lead point
Awareness of risks of delay leading to ischemia and perforation
Post-reduction monitoring and parental education on recurrence

resident_feedback_template: Strengths: You demonstrated strong diagnostic reasoning by recognizing the classic features of intussusception and appropriately ordering confirmatory imaging. Your management prioritized resuscitation and timely enema reduction. Communication with the family was clear and empathetic.Areas for Improvement: Consider refining the sequence of stabilization and diagnosis to minimize delays. Review the operative management, including technical steps of manual reduction and inspection for lead points.
